entry.content:
Oracle Text is a full-text search engine available out of the box in all modern Oracle Database distributions. Its capabilities are integrated absolutely seamlessly into SQL and it might be a decent choice for providing Google-like search in Oracle ecosystems.

In the real world, it is successfully used in many business-grade software (including shipped by Oracle). I frequently work with this sort of systems. Inevitably it means that I face with different kinds of issues including related to Oracle Text. In this post, I will share few basic queries that I find useful for starting troubleshooting problems in Oracle Text indexes.

General Information

The first query is not directly related to Oracle Text. Although, often it makes sense to start an investigation by getting a definition of the table you experience the problem with:

select dbms_metadata.get_ddl('TABLE','<TABLE_NAME>','<OWNER>') from dual;

The following 2 queries have a lot of information in common. Although I usually run them both. The first one generates a script that may be used to set up specified index. The second one generates a human-readable report describing index properties.

select ctx_report.create_index_script('<index_name>') from dual;
select ctx_report.describe_index('<index_name>') from dual;

Row-level queries

The question that arises almost always - are all rows of a table indexed? Here is a query that may answer it:

SELECT *
  FROM <TABLE_NAME>
 WHERE rowid not in (
        SELECT textkey
          FROM dr$files_content_idx$k
    );

Although, if some row isn't indexed, it doesn't necessary means that something is wrong. For example, NULL values aren't eligible for indexing. Also, the row may be simply waiting in the queue. Here is a query that shows rows pending to be processed:

SELECT t.*
  FROM ctxsys.dr$pending p
  JOIN <TABLE_NAME> t
    ON t.rowid = p.pnd_rowid;

Though "real" errors sometimes occur as well. You may find all affected rowids in issue-reporting table. Here is how to join it with your target table:

SELECT e.err_timestamp, e.err_text, t.*
  FROM ctxsys.dr$index_error e
  JOIN <TABLE_NAME> t
    ON t.rowid = e.ERR_TEXTKEY;

Summary queries

It also is easy to get an overview of what is going on with following queries. They select data from database views which are based on the same ctxsys.dr$pending and ctxsys.dr$index_error tables.

Number of rows pending to be indexed: 

  SELECT pnd_index_name index_name,
         count(1) count
    FROM ctxsys.ctx_user_pending
GROUP BY pnd_index_name
ORDER BY 2;

Errors count:

  SELECT err_index_name index_name,
         err_text error,
         count(1) count
    FROM ctx_user_index_errors
GROUP BY err_text,
         err_index_name;

Afterword

While Oracle Text is a black box in many aspects, it is possible to transparently check coverage of its indexes. It makes life of the maintaining personnel much easier. Though don't expect that you always will be able to extract some useful information from the error messages produced. Prepare yourself to face things like

DRG-11207: user filter command exited with status 3
DRG-00100: internal error, arguments : [50200],[drugi.c],[557],[],[]

and

DRG-11207: user filter command exited with status 1

You'll have to contact Oracle support to troubleshoot them. Still some of the messages are self-explaining. A couple of examples that I saw recently:

DRG-11207: user filter command exited with status 1
DRG-11223: Third-party filter indicates this document is password protected or encrypted.

DRG-11207: user filter command exited with status 1
DRG-11222: Third-party filter does not support this known document format.

entry.title: Walkthrough - Creating an Oracle Database Docker Image
entry.summary: Docker containerization is super hot nowadays. Among the things I like the most - hey, it allows me to run Linux software on my Mac which makes my life much easier. Oracle Database is one of the products that aren't shipped for OS X which I use frequently. Fortunately, Oracle doesn't …
entry.content:
Docker containerization is super hot nowadays. Among the things I like the most - hey, it allows me to run Linux software on my Mac which makes my life much easier. Oracle Database is one of the products that aren't shipped for OS X which I use frequently. Fortunately, Oracle doesn't want to leave developers working with their software aside of this revolution and supports running many of their product within containers. In this post, I will go through steps of setting up a container having Oracle Database on board. We will need just a couple of things for it:

  • Docker (surprised?)
  • Oracle account

Prepare the stage

In this guide we will build an Oracle Database Docker image ourselves. To do it, in the first place, we have to prepare a couple ingredients:

  1. Clone Oracle docker-images Git repository to your machine or download the repo as an archive and unzip it:

    git clone https://github.com/oracle/docker-images

    or

    curl -L https://github.com/oracle/docker-images/archive/master.zip > docker-images.zip
unzip docker-images.zip
mv docker-images-master docker-images

  2. Go to Oracle Database Software Downloads page and download x86-64 version of Oracle Database 12c Release 2 binaries.

    You will have to accept License Agreement and log in with your Oracle account.

  3. Put downloaded database distribution archive into docker-images/OracleDatabase/SingleInstance/dockerfiles/12.2.0.1 directory

    $ ls -l docker-images/OracleDatabase/SingleInstance/dockerfiles/12.2.0.1
total 6745656
-rw-r--r--  1 svovk  staff          62 Jul 17 09:35 Checksum.ee
-rw-r--r--  1 svovk  staff          62 Jul 17 09:35 Checksum.se2
-rw-r--r--  1 svovk  staff        2639 Jul 17 09:35 Dockerfile.ee
-rw-r--r--  1 svovk  staff        2645 Jul 17 09:35 Dockerfile.se2
-rwxr-xr-x  1 svovk  staff        1148 Jul 17 09:35 checkDBStatus.sh
-rwxr-xr-x  1 svovk  staff         905 Jul 17 09:35 checkSpace.sh
-rwxr-xr-x  1 svovk  staff        2953 Jul 17 09:35 createDB.sh
-rw-r--r--  1 svovk  staff        6878 Jul 17 09:35 db_inst.rsp
-rw-r--r--  1 svovk  staff        9203 Jul 17 09:35 dbca.rsp.tmpl
-rwxr-xr-x  1 svovk  staff        2250 Jul 17 09:35 installDBBinaries.sh
-rw-r--r--@ 1 svovk  staff  3453696911 Jul 17 11:24 linuxx64_12201_database.zip
-rwxr-xr-x  1 svovk  staff        6140 Jul 17 09:35 runOracle.sh
-rwxr-xr-x  1 svovk  staff        1015 Jul 17 09:35 runUserScripts.sh
-rwxr-xr-x  1 svovk  staff         758 Jul 17 09:35 setPassword.sh
-rwxr-xr-x  1 svovk  staff         876 Jul 17 09:35 setupLinuxEnv.sh
-rwxr-xr-x  1 svovk  staff         678 Jul 17 09:35 startDB.sh

Build the image

Ok, at this point everything is ready to build the image itself. It requires only 2 commands:

cd docker-images/OracleDatabase/SingleInstance/dockerfiles/
./buildDockerImage.sh -v 12.2.0.1 -e

We pass following parameters to buildDockerImage script:

  • -v specifies database version for which the image should be built
  • -e says that we are going to build enterprise edition database

Expect that it will take some time to build the image (on my Mid-2012 MacBook Pro it took about 30 minutes). At the end of the build process you'll see following message:

Oracle Database Docker Image for 'ee' version 12.2.0.1 is ready to be extended: 

--> oracle/database:12.2.0.1-ee

Build completed in 2005 seconds.

Now list of available docker images should contain oracle/database:12.2.0.1-ee

$ docker images
REPOSITORY               TAG                 IMAGE ID            CREATED             SIZE
oracle/database          12.2.0.1-ee         163d644d8a0c        12 hours ago        13.2GB
oraclelinux              7-slim              b1af4ba0cf19        11 days ago         117MB

Start the database!

All is ready to run a container based on the image we just created. But let me say few words about parameters that we will pass.

  • With -e we specify environment variables. Using them we define SID, PDB names and also password that will be set for SYS, SYSTEM, and PDBADMIN database users.
  • -p parameter publishes container ports to the host machine.
  • Finally, -v specifies bind mount for the directory that stores Oracle data files. You should replace /path/to/some/directory with some valid path on your computer.
docker run --name oracle-db12.2-ee \
-p 1521:1521 -p 5500:5500 \
-e ORACLE_SID=ORCL1 \
-e ORACLE_PDB=ORCLPDB1 \
-e ORACLE_PWD=welcome \
-v /path/to/some/directory:/opt/oracle/oradata \
oracle/database:12.2.0.1-ee

After executing the command, give it some time and you'll see following message:

SQL> Disconnected from Oracle Database 12c Enterprise Edition Release 12.2.0.1.0 - 64bit Production
The Oracle base remains unchanged with value /opt/oracle
#########################
DATABASE IS READY TO USE!
#########################
The following output is now a tail of the alert.log:

Not surprisingly, it indicates that your Oracle is up and running. Congratulations!

Create a new user

The first thing that I usually do once I have a freshly built database - creating a user. Let's connect via SQL*Plus and set one up!

  1. While our container is running, open additional terminal session and execute docker stop -t 60 oracle-db12.2-ee. 

    $ docker exec -it oracle-db12.2-ee /bin/bash
[oracle@1e0aed256c62 ~]$ sqlplus / as sysdba

SQL*Plus: Release 12.2.0.1.0 Production on Wed Jul 18 07:36:15 2018

Copyright (c) 1982, 2016, Oracle.  All rights reserved.

Connected to:
Oracle Database 12c Enterprise Edition Release 12.2.0.1.0 - 64bit Production

SQL>

  2. I also have a habit to check in which instance we are on before doing anything, it might be completely not needed here, but:

    SQL> select instance_name from v$instance;

INSTANCE_NAME
----------------
ORCL1

  3. Let's create a user named test which is identified by testpwd password. Of course, you may change the name and password to whatever you want. 

    SQL> ALTER SESSION SET CONTAINER = orclpdb1;

Session altered.

SQL> grant connect, resource to test identified by testpwd container=current;

Grant succeeded.

SQL> GRANT CREATE SESSION TO test container=current;

Grant succeeded.

That's it!

We are all set now. We have a database running. We have a user in it. For reference, here is configuration that I used to connect SQLDeveloper via test user to the database

How to stop/restart created container

Sooner or later you will need to stop the container. An important thing to keep in mind - it is recommended to give Oracle additional time for shutdown activities. By default, when you stop a container Docker waits 10 seconds and then kills it. This may be too tight for Oracle Database. Let's make Docker wait up to one minute.

docker stop -t 60 oracle-db12.2-ee

If you didn't remove stopped container, it remains available and you may start it again with following

docker start oracle-db12.2-ee

This command will start the container in background mode. You might also want to check its logs:

docker logs oracle-db12.2-ee



That's all that have for this post, my best wishes in using Docker!

entry.title: How to authenticate EBS users in JSP pages
entry.summary: Almost always Oracle Applications Framework is the preferable way for creating new pages for your Oracle EBS ecosystem. But in rare cases, OAF fails to fit the needs. For example, you might need precise control over HTML code that is rendered. In such cases, Java Servlet Pages might be a …
entry.content:
Almost always Oracle Applications Framework is the preferable way for creating new pages for your Oracle EBS ecosystem. But in rare cases, OAF fails to fit the needs. For example, you might need precise control over HTML code that is rendered. In such cases, Java Servlet Pages might be a good fallback.

This fallback comes at a price though - in servlet pages, you have to do a lot of things manually. This post is to share a code snippet that might be used for authenticating Oracle EBS users in a custom JSP page. Often, it is the first thing that is done.

<%@ page
 language = "java"
 import = "oracle.apps.fnd.common.WebAppsContext"
 import = "oracle.apps.fnd.common.WebRequestUtil"
%>
<%
    WebAppsContext ctx = null;
    try {
        String userName = null;
        ctx = WebRequestUtil.validateContext(request, response);
        if (ctx == null){
            throw new RuntimeException("Unable to get context");
        }
        userName = ctx.getUserName();
        %><h2>Hello, <%=userName%></h2><%
    }finally{
        if (ctx != null){
            ctx.freeWebAppsContext();
        }
    }
%>

This code is very straightforward, it gets WebAppsContext object which is then used to request current username.

WebAppsContext is a quite basic object that tracks key Oracle EBS context information like responsibility, organization and etc. Behind the scenes, all these information is obtained based on JSESSIONID cookie that is set for all pages under http://your-url/OA_HTML/ by the login screen.

entry.title: Benchmark - reading integer values
entry.summary: I like solving algorithmic problems. One of the routines that you do working on such tasks is implementing code for reading input data. In the challenges your code has to provide right answers in a specified timeframe and to achieve this sometimes it isn't enough to tune your algorithm - it …
entry.content:
I like solving algorithmic problems. One of the routines that you do working on such tasks is implementing code for reading input data. In the challenges your code has to provide right answers in a specified timeframe and to achieve this sometimes it isn't enough to tune your algorithm - it may be important to read input data fast. Especially it may be noticeable on problems with huge input datasets.

To pick the fastest way I created a benchmark comparing different approaches for reading integers from a file (it is usual format of input data):

  • (measureScanner) Scanner(File source) Scanner constructed based on FileReader
  • (measureFileReaderScanner)Scanner constructed using Scanner(Readable source) constructor where Readable is FileReader
  • (measureBufferedFileReaderScanner) Scanner constructed using Scanner(Readable source) constructor where Readable is FileReader wrapped in BufferedReader
  • (measureMyScanner) a bit reworked version of MyScanner class (original one is published on Codeforces)

And here are results that I get on my Mid 2012 MacBook Pro:

Benchmark                                           Mode  Cnt        Score       Error  Units
TextScanBenchmark.measureBufferedFileReaderScanner  thrpt   25  1008316.536 ±  5711.553  ops/s
TextScanBenchmark.measureFileReaderScanner          thrpt   25  1016116.706 ±  8823.260  ops/s
TextScanBenchmark.measureMyScanner                  thrpt   25  6315469.046 ± 81171.672  ops/s
TextScanBenchmark.measureScanner                    thrpt   25  1031693.182 ±  7556.776  ops/s

And the same numbers on a plot (red lines show errors)

What can we conclude based on this?

  • first of all, it doesn't matter how you create Scanner class - passing a File to the constructor, FileReader class or FileReader class wrapped in BufferedReader (Scanner class itself has buffering logic and adding another layer of buffering doesn't add any value)
  • to speed up the file reading process a custom class may be used (my example)

entry.summary:

entry.content:
I frequently work on enhancing functionality of Event Handlers and Process Extensions developed by 3rd party companies and relativery often notice doubtful patterns in the code. Here is one from top 10 list. Many developers use following approach for iterating over selected MultiList attribute values:

String selected[] = dataObject.getValue("Page Three.MultiList01").toString().split(";");
for (int j = 0; j < selected.length; j++) {
    System.out.println(selected[j]);
    // ...
}

First of all, this code has some overhead as it concatenates selected multilist values into one string and then splits this string. Then, it relays on toString() result which behavior is not guaranteed. I would prefer following approach to do the same (in Java 7)

for (IAgileList selected : 
        ((IAgileList) dataObject.getValue("Page Three.MultiList01")).getSelection()){
    System.out.println((String) selected.getValue());
    // ...
}

Yes, it's a bit more complicated but I like that now one may actually read the code.

In Groovy the same approach may be used in combination with a closure which makes our code even more expressive and shorter:

dataObject.getValue("Page Three.MultiList01").getSelection().each { selected ->
    println(selected.value)
}

entry.title: Agile PLM Dashboard Optional Tabs - database tables
entry.summary: Recently I was working on a data issue which prevented a person from using Optional Tab 1 of his Dashboard. When the user clicked on the tab, Agile showed "Object does not exists" error and nothing else appeared. Researching this issue brought me to understanding of some relations in Agile …
entry.content:
Recently I was working on a data issue which prevented a person from using Optional Tab 1 of his Dashboard. When the user clicked on the tab, Agile showed "Object does not exists" error and nothing else appeared. Researching this issue brought me to understanding of some relations in Agile DB Schema which I would like to discuss in this post.

I don't think Dashboard DB structure is something that Oracle changes frequently, but I should mention that I worked on the issue in Agile PLM 9.3.6.4 and didn't validate if all relations are the same in any other PLM versions.

Dashboard

As for many other setup entities, database schema journey starts with one of the most basic tables in Agile PLM schema - nodetable:

SELECT id, lpad('+ ',level + 1) || description node
FROM nodetable n
CONNECT BY n.parentId = PRIOR n.id
START WITH n.description = 'Dashboard Management'

This query shows us hierarchy under Dashboard Management node (Java Client) Admin -> System Settings -> Dashboard Management. Here is what it shows in my environment:

ID          NODE
----------  ----------------------
2000000001  + Dashboard Management  
...
2000000111   + Optional Tab 1
2000000112    + Table 1
2000000113    + Table 2
2000000114    + Table 3
2000000115    + Table 4
...

Now we have node ids and may query what Optional Tab 1 tables actually display:

SELECT tableId, queryId, tableName, userId
FROM query_table
WHERE tableId IN (2000000111, 2000000112, 2000000113, 2000000114)
  AND userId = <userId>

Few important points about query_table:

  • As you know, each user sets content of his/her optional tab tables. That is why query_table has userId column (it is a foreign key to agileuser table).
  • queryId is a foreign key to query table
  • tableName is a user-friendly name of the table

Note: when you define a custom dashboard table with query for all users userId will be set to NULL.

Issue

In my case, root cause of the error was following - one of the query ids specified in query_table wasn't actually defined in query table. To fix the problem, I deleted query_table row that had inconsistent data which moved the tab table to no-query-assigned state.

Please note that it is not recommended to apply any data fixes to Agile Database Schema without confirming with Oracle that they are valid.

Other tables to check

When you see an issue like that it always worth to check other tables that might have orphan records referring to the same missing row. Here are few additional tables that might refer to a query id:

  • select_list table contains information about fields to be displayed

    select * select_list where query_id = <queryId>

  • foldering table stores information about folders under which queries are stored

    select * from foldering where objectid = <queryId>

  • criteria table contains information about query filters

    select * from criteria where query_id = <queryId>

entry.title: Weblogic Data Sources in Agile PLM Groovy Handlers
entry.summary: In this note, I will demonstrate how to configure JDBC Data Source in Weblogic and then use it in Agile PLM Groovy Handler. Oracle doesn't recommend query or modify Agile DB schema directly, although, code interacting with some other DB or schema is a valid approach. Please note that depending …
entry.content:
In this note, I will demonstrate how to configure JDBC Data Source in Weblogic and then use it in Agile PLM Groovy Handler. Oracle doesn't recommend query or modify Agile DB schema directly, although, code interacting with some other DB or schema is a valid approach. Please note that depending on the particular integration case it might not be the best option to retrieve the data directly from external DB (but I won't discuss different approaches here).

Configure JDBC Data Source

  1. Log in Weblogic Administration Console

  2. To start configuration change press 'Lock & Edit'

  3. Navigate Services -> Data Sources in your domain (Domain Structure pane)

  4. Click New button and choose Generic Data Source

  5. Specify Name, JNDI Name, Database Type and click Next

  6. Choose DB driver to be used and click Next

  7. Leave transaction options default

  8. Populate DB connectivity data - database name, server name, port, account and press Next

  9. Test configuration and click Next

  10. On the next screen choose servers to deploy created Data Source and press Finish

  11. To make the changes effective press 'Activate Changes' button

Use created Data Source in Groovy Handler

Usage is actually pretty straightforward, you may find an example below

import com.agile.agileDSL.ScriptObj.IBaseScriptObj
import groovy.sql.Sql
import javax.naming.InitialContext

void invokeScript(IBaseScriptObj obj) {

    Sql sql = new Sql(new InitialContext().lookup("My JDBC Data Source"))

    sql.eachRow("select 1  test from dual"){ row ->
        obj.logDebug("selected number is ${row.test}")
    }
}

Note that we construct Sql using the DataSource. Each operation will use a Connection from the DataSource pool and close it when the operation is completed putting it back into the pool. This makes explit sql.close() call not required.

entry.title: How to install Oracle Developer Suite on Windows 10
entry.summary: In spite of the fact that Oracle Developer Suite is certified with Windows 10, ODS installation that I did some time ago wasn't smooth. It required few tricks to make it work. Below you may find step by step description of the process. Note that I reference few Oracle Support …
entry.content:
In spite of the fact that Oracle Developer Suite is certified with Windows 10, ODS installation that I did some time ago wasn't smooth. It required few tricks to make it work. Below you may find step by step description of the process. Note that I reference few Oracle Support resources in the post, to download them you'll need Oracle Support subscription.

Downloading

For the installation you will need

  • Base software media: Oracle Developer Suite 10g (10.1.2.0.2). You may download both disks from Oracle

  • Following patches from Oracle Support

    • Patch 10396165 WINDOWS 7 CERT:NEED AN INSTALL ONE OFF PATCH FOR IDS 10.1.2.0.2
    • Patch 5983622 Oracle Application Server 10g Release 2 (10.1.2) Patch Set 3 (10.1.2.

Installation

  • Oracle Installation utility is not able to check memory settings correctly and that's why it is required to explicitly specify minimum swap file size before the installation: Start Menu > click on Settings > Adjust the appearance and performance of Windows > Advanced > Change (Virtual memory section) > Uncheck the automatic setting, set the initial size to 256 MB and set maximum size to whatever you need (for example 8GB) and click Set. You may revert this change back after the installation.

  • Reboot your machine as Windows will request after the change

  • Run setup.exe delivered via Patch 10396165 with following command (via elevated command prompt)

    setup.exe -ignoreSysPrereqs

  • Click Next

  • Specify path to products.xml from Disk 1 from ODS archive (path should not contain any spaces) and click Next

  • Choose Complete Installation and click Next

  • Press Install and wait for installation completion

  • During the installation it will ask you where Disk 2 of ODS Base software media is located

Upgrading to ODS 10.1.2.3

  • If you performed all above steps correctly, now you should have ODS 10.1.2.0.2 installed, let's upgrade it to 10.1.2.3

  • Unpack content of Patch 5983622 and click on setup

  • We may run this installer without any command-line options, but it will prompt if we would like to ignore our OS version (choose y)

  • Choose same directory which was used during previous installation

  • Then choose 1st product

  • And click Install

Other References

There is no dedicated Oracle Support note describing installation process for Windows 10. Oracle suggests using one specified below. Please refer it for additional details.

  • Certification of Oracle Developer Suite 10g (10.1.2) on Windows 7 (32-bit) (Doc ID 1292919.1)

entry.title: Analyzing Agile PLM log files with Python
entry.summary: Sometimes it is useful to get an overview of log files generated by a system and Agile PLM is not an exception. For logging Agile uses log4j library which is capable of producing very parsing-friendly formats. Although in practice the system is usually configured to generate plain text files in …
entry.content:
Sometimes it is useful to get an overview of log files generated by a system and Agile PLM is not an exception. For logging Agile uses log4j library which is capable of producing very parsing-friendly formats. Although in practice the system is usually configured to generate plain text files in which log entries look like one below

2000-10-10 00:01:21,043 <ChangeHistoryService:ERROR>    process change notification failed:
ORA-00001: unique constraint (AGILE.CHANGE_HISTORY_PK) violated

ORA-00001: unique constraint (AGILE.CHANGE_HISTORY_PK) violated

java.sql.BatchUpdateException: ORA-00001: unique constraint (AGILE.CHANGE_HISTORY_PK) violated

    at oracle.jdbc.driver.OraclePreparedStatement.executeBatch(OraclePreparedStatement.java:10401)
    at oracle.jdbc.driver.OracleStatementWrapper.executeBatch(OracleStatementWrapper.java:230)
    at weblogic.jdbc.wrapper.PreparedStatement.executeBatch(PreparedStatement.java:205)
    at com.agile.pc.cmserver.base.BaseRouteDAO.insertHistoryRecords(BaseRouteDAO.java:4797)
    at com.agile.pc.cmserver.base.BaseRouteDAO.insertHistoryRecord(BaseRouteDAO.java:4741)
    at com.agile.pc.cmserver.base.BaseRouteDAO.insertChangeHistory(BaseRouteDAO.java:4720)
    at com.agile.pc.cmserver.base.BaseRouteDAO.insertChangeHistory(BaseRouteDAO.java:4678)
    at com.agile.pc.cmserver.base.BaseRouteDAO.logTAHistory(BaseRouteDAO.java:402)
    at com.agile.pc.cmserver.notification.ChangeHistoryDAO.logTAHistories(ChangeHistoryDAO.java:559)
    at com.agile.pc.cmserver.notification.ChangeHistoryService.transferSignOffs(ChangeHistoryService.java:379)
    at com.agile.pc.cmserver.notification.ChangeHistoryService.processChangeHistory(ChangeHistoryService.java:286)
    at com.agile.pc.cmserver.notification.ChangeHistoryService.processChangeHistories(ChangeHistoryService.java:119)
    at com.agile.pc.cmserver.notification.NotifyTask.processChangeHistory(NotifyTask.java:566)
    at com.agile.pc.cmserver.notification.NotifyTask.run(NotifyTask.java:214)
    at java.util.TimerThread.mainLoop(Timer.java:555)
    at java.util.TimerThread.run(Timer.java:505)

Just for reference, it was produced by appender with following configuration

<appender name="AgileLog" class="org.apache.log4j.RollingFileAppender">
    <param name="File"   value="${agile.log.dir}/agile.log" />
    <layout class="org.apache.log4j.PatternLayout">
        <param name="ConversionPattern" value="%d\t<%c{1}:%p>\t%m\n"/>
    </layout>
</appender>

Definitely, for automated log file analysis, it is better to reconfigure log4j. Although, mentioned layout is still something we may parse and process. Well, it's not the best option but sometimes you don't have time to wait until new log files will be generated. Let's go through one example.

Log files to be analyzed

Agile PLM produces a number of log files. In this analysis, I will use only one of them: agile.log. This log file is generated by AgileLog appender which is used by various logging categories throughout log.xml configuration.

Preprocessing

Concatenate all the files we are going to process 

agile.log
agile.log.1
agile.log.2
agile.log.3
agile.log.4
agile.log.5

into a one file

cat agile.log* > agile_all_logs

after that, let's convert agile_all_logs into CSV format which is much better for further processing. Here is a python script for it:

#!/usr/bin/env python3
import re
import csv
import os

input_file = 'in/agile_all_logs'
output_file = 'out/agile_all_logs.csv'

output_dir = os.path.dirname(output_file)
if not os.path.exists(output_dir):
    os.makedirs(output_dir)

with open(output_file, 'w', newline='') as outf:
    csv_writer = csv.writer(outf, quoting=csv.QUOTE_MINIMAL, lineterminator='\n')

    print("processing "+input_file+"...")
    with open(input_file, 'r') as inp:
        # variable to store and accumulate logical log entry
        row = None
        line_num = 0
        for line in inp:
            line_num += 1
            # we consider row that starts with YYYY-MM-DD date as a start
            # of new log entry
            try:
                if re.match(r"\d{4}-\d{2}-\d{2}", line) is not None:
                    if row is not None:
                        row[3] = row[3].rstrip() 
                        csv_writer.writerow(row) 
                    # number of entries separated with tab
                    row = line.split(maxsplit=3)
                else:
                    row[3] = row[3] + line
            except IndexError:
                print("Warning IndexError on line #" + str(line_num))
                # skip existing content
                row = None

        csv_writer.writerow(row)

After the processing our log entries should look like following

2000-10-10,"00:01:21,043",<ChangeHistoryService:ERROR>,"process change notification failed:

    at weblogic.jdbc.wrapper.PreparedStatement.executeBatch(PreparedStatement.java:205)
    at com.agile.pc.cmserver.base.BaseRouteDAO.insertHistoryRecords(BaseRouteDAO.java:4797)
    at com.agile.pc.cmserver.base.BaseRouteDAO.insertHistoryRecord(BaseRouteDAO.java:4741)
    at com.agile.pc.cmserver.base.BaseRouteDAO.insertChangeHistory(BaseRouteDAO.java:4720)
    at com.agile.pc.cmserver.base.BaseRouteDAO.insertChangeHistory(BaseRouteDAO.java:4678)
    at com.agile.pc.cmserver.base.BaseRouteDAO.logTAHistory(BaseRouteDAO.java:402)
    at com.agile.pc.cmserver.notification.ChangeHistoryDAO.logTAHistories(ChangeHistoryDAO.java:559)
    at com.agile.pc.cmserver.notification.ChangeHistoryService.transferSignOffs(ChangeHistoryService.java:379)
    at com.agile.pc.cmserver.notification.ChangeHistoryService.processChangeHistory(ChangeHistoryService.java:286)
    at com.agile.pc.cmserver.notification.ChangeHistoryService.processChangeHistories(ChangeHistoryService.java:119)

    at java.util.TimerThread.run(Timer.java:505)"

Analysis

In this part, we will generate a summary table showing top error messages. To do it we will use python data analysis library called Pandas. It allows us do the whole analysis in few simple steps.

1. Import

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np

df = pd.read_csv('out/agile_all_logs.csv',
    names = ('date', 'time', 'source', 'message'),
    parse_dates=['date'])

at this stage imported data frame has following format

2. Adjust

In this step we

  • split 'source' column into 2 columns
  • may also drop columns that will not be included in the analysis 
tmp = df.source.str.extract('<(\w+):(\w+)>', expand=True)
df['class'] = tmp[0]
df['log_level'] = tmp[1]
df = df.drop(labels=['source', 'date', 'time'], axis=1)

3. Group

# group the data by class, log_leve, and message and export to csv file
grouped = df.groupby(by=['class', 'log_level', 'message'])\
    .size()\
    .reset_index(name='counts').sort_values(by='counts', ascending=False)

Now we see top log entries

4. Export

We might also export results

grouped.to_csv('out/summary.csv')

entry.content:
Groovy Script PXs were introduced in Agile 9.3.0 and since then conquered the hearts of many Agile PLM users. I find myself using Groovy Scripts very frequently as it allows deliver product faster and make your code way more expressive. In this post, I will go through steps to set up your Eclipse IDE for Groovy PX Development.

1. Install Groovy-Eclipse plugin into your Eclipse IDE

  • Visit Groovy-Eclipse GitHub wiki page: Groovy-Eclipse

  • Copy installation URL for your Eclipse version from Releases or Snapshot Builds section

  • Open Eclipse and navigate 'Help ->Install New Software...' from the top menu

  • Paste copied URL and press Enter

  • Check 'Groovy-Eclipse Feature' and compilers to be used

    Note: Most recent Agile version at the moment is 9.3.6.4 and it uses groovy-2.4.6. You may find your Groovy version by executing following from your Agile PLM home

    find . -iname groovy*

2. Create Groovy Project

  • Navigate File -> New -> Other

  • Select "Groovy Project"

  • Type project name and click Finish

  • Copy agileclasses.jar and AgileAPI.jar files to your local machine. Here is quick and easy way to find them:

    cd $AGILE_HOME
find . -iname agileclasses.jar
find . -iname AgileAPI.jar

  • Go to Project properties and add copied JARs

  • Right click on 'src' and choose new -> other

  • Choose Groovy class

  • Fill create a new Groovy class form

  • Paste Agile Groovy Event code into created class file

    import com.agile.agileDSL.ScriptObj.IBaseScriptObj

void invokeScript(IBaseScriptObj obj) {
  //script body starts here
}
